title: Spasa Garda
text: Spasa Pavlović (; ca. 1880 – November 7, 1912), known as Spasa Garda (Спаса Гарда, "Spasa the Guard") or Zmaj (Змај, "the Dragon"), was a Serbian Chetnik commander in <a href="Old%20Serbia">Old Serbia</a> during the <a href="Macedonian%20Struggle">Macedonian Struggle</a> (1903–1908). He received his nicknames from his high stature and bravery, and could be entrusted with highly secretive missions. He was born in the village of <a href="Stan%C4%8Da%2C%20Republic%20of%20Macedonia">Stanča</a> near <a href="Kriva%20Palanka">Kriva Palanka</a>, <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> (modern <a href="R.%20Macedonia">R. Macedonia</a>). From 1903, he was a "jatak" ("<a href="hajduk">hajduk</a> helper") for the Serbian bands whom he led the way in the woods and hills, and since 1904 he was a "vojvoda" (duke) in the Kriva Palanka area. His band defended the Kriva Palanka region from the IMRO, securing the Kriva river, which region was controlled by Serbian bands and where all villages were adhering to the Patriarchate (and not the <a href="Bulgarian%20Exarchate">Bulgarian Exarchate</a>) and included in the <a href="Serbian%20Chetnik%20Organization">Serbian Chetnik Organization</a>. Spasa participated in all major battles on the left bank of the <a href="Vardar">Vardar</a> river. There, he helped destroy the local Bulgarian secret organization and Turkish (Ottoman) government. He is famed for his bravery in the <a href="battle%20on%20Pakli%C5%A1te">battle on Paklište</a>. After the <a href="Young%20Turk%20Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> (1908), he returned to his village and lived a peaceful life. However, with the breakout of the <a href="First%20Balkan%20War">First Balkan War</a>, he joined the unit of <a href="Vojin%20Popovi%C4%87-Vuk">Vojin Popović-Vuk</a>, as the Serbian <a href="vanguard">vanguard</a>, and participated in all battles from the Serbian border to <a href="Prilep">Prilep</a>. He was wounded but declined medical care. He was <a href="killed%20in%20action">killed in action</a> in the fights for Prilep, on November 7, 1912, on the <a href="Alina%C4%8Dki%20vis">Alinački vis</a>. He was buried in Prilep.
